channel.title: [JXGC] XML to GUI- and Object-creation
channel.description: Hello! As I have been creating a tool recently with which you can create both Objects and setup GUI:s via XML-parsing, I wanted to hear some feedback on this... Whether it would be a great idea to continue on it, or not (perhaps if others that are better/more flexible already exists?). When I have searched on the matter, I havn't really found alot of tools... The one I found was SwiXML, but that was only ment for creating of Swing-GUI:s. However, as said, mine can create almost all (all that does not require what my program lacks (will name some of these drawbacks later on)) Objects. As I don't know yet whether this will be released open-source, or not, I can atleast show you some of the stuff... A sample picture and the XML-file that created it. Yz85Racer: Well, this very project have been put aside on my project-schedule, but, it won’t be fully gone. First I thought I had messed up the code, and didn’t know what to do to fix it. Then I decompiled a working version and compared the source code between these versions. There were no changes to the new version, which indeed worked, so I tried it once again, and it suddenly worked again (I have no idea what happened earlier).

But today, I got much better plans. My object-loader package which I were first trying to make to be able to create this GUI-creator, that I couldn’t create before, have now been created, and still needs to be fixed. But since I managed to do that, I have plans on creating a whole new language, which I also plan on expanding to cover easy GUI-creation. That is where I stand today.

These plans have merged because I didn’t feel comfortable with the XML-creation of GUI:s. It would take too long to create a nice program, unless I made a standalone program using some kind of nodes etc. to create this XML-file (by adding data to text-fields etc.).

item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

[quote=“ephemeral, post:10, topic:231999”]Taharok: The LookAndFeel is actually changed after initialization… All JComponents have a method called updateUI, with which you change the look of the JComponent, after you have changed UIManager.setLookAndFeel(…) to another LookAndFeel. I had to make a little “ugly-hack” in this package to actually show the LookAndFeel properly… Else it wouldn’t be shown.

Everytime you add a new Object, which in fact is an instance of JComponent, or JFrame with JRootPane and JLayeredPane, I also call their updateUI() respectively.

This GUI-creation tool is originally only made to set the LookAndFeel when the GUI is started… Changing the LookAndFeel can be manually done later in an ActionListener class or similar for different JComponents etc. This tool is not ment to handle everything for a user, but only the specific creation of the GUI.

lawl: The LookAndFeel I use, is “com.jtattoo.plaf.acryl.AcrylLookAndFeel”, which is a theme-LookAndFeel in the LookAndFeel-package called “JTattoo”.[/quote]
iirc, you only have to call updateui on the topmost jframe, not on every component, that worked for an old app i made

item.title: [JXGC] XML to GUI- and Object-creation
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“ephemeral, post:6, topic:231999”]Taharok: That is not what I mean… I am not sure what you mean totally, but, my first impression is that you wish to store references to different LAF’s somewhere? If so, then just grab the correct LookAndFeel Object when you click on for instance a JMenuItem representing that LAF.

Or do you instead mean that I should have different LAF’s on different JComponents at the same time? If this is the case, I will just have to add an attribute to the Object-Elements that can tell us whether to change the LAF for that Object in particular (or just wait until I can actually call on static methods etc.).[/quote]

You’re scripts are parsed and then run in the initialization part of the program. Activity is not enabled until after the script is run through. Look And Feel changes must be done before user interface objects are displayed (so, basically, in the initialization part of the entire program). Thus, to change the LAF, you need to do it inside the script. And also, it seems you have not changed the LAF in the Swing package before. It is done statically through the class, UIManager. It has nothing to do with JMenuItems and is a pain in the butt when run through an external plugin, but still is possible. As long as the LAF Jar file is included in the classpath and the same parameters apply for the method call, it should load. But any way you slice it, you need to modify the LAF through UIManager, thus needing access to call a static method during the initialization of the program, which is in your script.

item.title: [JXGC] XML to GUI- and Object-creation
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“ephemeral, post:4, topic:231999”]Taharok: Well, you can sort of say that the feature “multiple LAF plugin” support have already been made… If you think of it like this:

  1. Add an Object to the main-Element that specifies either just a String, or a new LookAndFeel-instance. Name their IDs to lets say “LAF1”, “LAF2” etc.

  2. Where you have created your rendering-process, looking similar to this:

Application application = JXGC.render("../../res/GUI.xml");

You now have an instance of Application reachable for use. This class have a few methods that can be used for your application. For instance, the method “Object getObject(String)”, which returns an Object that have been added to the application… Note: All Objects created using this tool, will be stored in there, in a Map, where key is the ID of the Object (no case-sensitivity).[/quote]

You said your script doesn’t support static references, so you couldn’t technically change the LAF of the Swing package.
